Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Cyberinstrument for AI-Enabled Computational Science & Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to acquire an instrument focusing on Artificial Intelligence to drive fundamental research and enable applications of existing methodologies. The instrumentation extends the supercomputer at the institution and would serve as catalysts for academic partnerships in the state among Clemson, Medical University of S.C. (MUSC), USC, and some HBCUs.

The Instrument extends the supercomputer at the institution and enables research on: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Computational Intelligence, Deep Learning, and Statistical Methods. The instrument enables research on Biomedical Data Science and Informatics, including the development of tools and deep learning methods for third generation sequencing data, new machine-learning algorithms for biomedical knowledge discovery systems. The Instrument enables research on root nodulation in legumes, cancer biology, and genomics algorithms; Visual Computing. It also enables research on fundamental problems related to physical simulation and numerical control problems spanning broadly from predictive scientific visualization to production of artificial sampling data for Deep Neural Network Training and to the control and safety assurance of real-world artifacts such as autonomous vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation award provided hardware that supported fundamental research and enabled applications of artificial intelligence. We purchased two DGX A100 servers and 14 PowerEdge R750: Intel 8358 nodes, each with dual NVIDIA A100 GPU cards and InfiniBand interfaces. All of the funds have been expended and the system was in full production as of the end of the award.  The instrumentation extended the Palmetto supercomputer at Clemson University and serves as a catalyst for academic partnerships in the state, including the Medical University of South Carolina, the University of South Carolina, and HBCUs within South Carolina.

 

The intellectual merit of this research includes five areas: Computational intelligence and machine learning  (ML), AI for biomedical data science and informatics (BDSI), AI-enabled research in Visual Computing, AI for computational materials science, and AI for intelligent engineered systems. More than 40 graduate students and postdocs performed research that was supported by the computer nodes bought by this grant. At least 45 publications have resulted by the end of the award. Additionally, the computer nodes have been used for teaching deep learning and machine learning courses at the School of Computing, Clemson University. More than 100 students utilized the computer nodes for their course projects annually in a three-year time period.  In addition to students supported as a part of the research teams named in the award, the Clemson Research Computing and Data Engagement team used the nodes to support the training of graduate students, postdocs, and faculty in Pytorch training classes that were accessible to participants across the Clemson campus and to our research collaborators.
